threads.author: kabutokun5373
threads.content:
Hello, I have a problem with an OEM motherboard, "IS8XM rev1.0" from a M93P Lenovo for Intel Haswell CPUs. I know it's old at this point but I like fix stuff.
At first it was not POSTing, and it wasn't beeping when removing the RAMs. After a lot of testing, at one point I noticed that it had 2 SPI/BIOS chips side by side (there is a 3rd one with 8MB very close to the superIO), and I thought that maybe one of them worked as a backup, so for one of them I shorted the CLK pin to GND while turning on the PC and that's the only way I can make the motherboard POST

threads.author: kabutokun5373
threads.content:
I read some good info here: https://www.badcaps.net/forum/troubleshooting-hardware-devices-and-electronics-theory/troubleshooting-desktop-motherboards-graphics-cards-and-pc-peripherals/bios-schematic-requests/80221-lenovo-thinkcentre-m93p-bios
User "SMDFlea" said:
```The M93p comes with either a single bios chip or 2. Yours has 2 (12MB split across 2 X chips, 8MB + 4MB)```
The chip I shorted above was the 4MB one (MXIC 25L3273E), I don't have to do anything with the other one (MXIC 25L6473E), so how it's possible that this makes the motherboard work?
Doing this "trick" allowed me to update the BIOS using the regular motherboard vendor tools running them from the same machine, but the problem persists, it won't POST normally by itself, it only works when shorting the CLK pin of the 4MB chip, any idea/suggestions?

threads.author: kabutokun5373
threads.content:
I still have this problem I want to get back to it.
My theory at this point is that the BIOS bootblock is corrupted and by messing with the clock pin of the 4MB chip I'm forcing the motherboard to run an alternative code path which still works so it POSTs that way.
The bootblock is not normally written when you run the default vendor BIOS flashing tools, that's why performing a regular BIOS update didn't fix the issue.
I tried to use intel FPT to flash the whole BIOS ROM but Lenovo added write-protection and I couldn't remove it via NVAR modding.
I also tried to use an external programmer (CH341A) to flash the chips and it could not read/write, the 8MB chip (MX25L6473E) says this on its datasheet "Permanently fixed QE bit, QE=1; and 4 I/O mode is enabled" and "The flash always performs Quad I/O mode", which means that it can't be used as a simple SPI device (with single MOSI/MISO lines) because it's in permanent QuadEnable mode from factory; this greatly limits my options for external programmers.
I even have another Haswell motherboard (MSI Z97 MATE) with what seems to be a corrupted BIOS too: it beeps when no RAM memory is inserted but with memory inserted (I've tested many modules on different slots) there are no beeps yet it doesn't POST, and while I don't have an oscilloscope at hand, when probing the clock pin of the BIOS chip with a multimeter I see constant activity. Unfortunately for me this 2nd mobo also has the same 8MB chip "MX25L6473E" üò¶
At this point my *only option* to fix both motherboards is to power on the Lenovo mobo using the mentioned *trick*, somehow remove the write-protection on the original Lenovo BIOS (I know assembly x86/x64 but I have not modded any BIOS before) so I can use intel FPT for full ROM flashing, use it to hot-swap the MSI chip (so flashing the MSI BIOS while inserted on the Lenovo mobo), and with this one fixed then flash the Lenovo chip on its own mobo with a non-corrupted BIOS so it always POST by itself

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content:
Given the symptoms you've described, I do believe what is happening is the chipset is receiving an over-current signal for the nonworking ports and is disabling their data lines. The motherboard doesn't implement any functionality to cut VBUS, so the +5 V is always present. You already measured VBUS to GND and found no short, so the port isn't the issue.

I would start by getting pictures and measuring the outputs of each of those transistors down there: `UD81`, `UD82`, `UD83`, `UD66`, and `UCD120`. If we do verify this as the issue and you just want to fix it and don't care about the root cause, you should just be able to remove the offending transistor(s).

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: A power supply and thermal camera certainly helps to (safely) find a shorted component. I would recommend watching some videos by northwestrepair on YouTube to get a general idea of troubleshooting steps. Really, all you'll be able to do with just a multimeter is confirm that there is a short on some rail. You won't know which component is the problem.

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content:
Ah, okay, sorry. You are correct that those are BAV70Ws, not transistors as I assumed. It's still possible that there is a communication loss because pin 1 for the gates I'm about to talk about comes from there, but I did some more research and found a schematic for a very similar board and someone with the same issue.

It looks like `SU3` and `SU4` are XOR gates that actually terminate the OC signal into the CPU. I found a thread on a Chinese repair forum (https://www.chinafix.com/thread-1378327-1-1.html) that mentions a bad pull-up resistor on pin 2 of those gates (`H_CORETYPE1`) causing this exact issue. I would check voltages on each of those pins, especially that pin 2. Not sure how likely it is that it's the same fault considering I think that would cause none of the ports to work, but we're still on the right track.

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content:
No, you don't have to remove `SU3`. Try measuring the voltage on `UCR197`, `UR166`, and `UR181`; perhaps we have multiple signals being pulled low. The CPU seems to handle two of the USB 3 OC signals but the chipset handles the rest. Also check that `PMR82`, `PMR83`, `PMR84`, `PMR85`, and `PMR130` are all present as they look to be pull-ups for unused signals.

CPU: `S_USB3_OC#34` (`SU3`), `S_USB3_OC#56` (`SU4`)
Chipset: `S_USB3_OC#12` (`UR181`), `S_USB3D1_OC#12` (`UCR197`), `S_USB_OC_#3456` (`UR166`)
Unused (connected to chipset): `PM_USB_OC#1` (`PMR82`), `PM_USB_OC#3` (`PMR83`), `PM_USB_OC#4` (`PMR85`), `PM_USB_OC#5` (`PMR84`), `PM_USB_OC#6` (`PMR130`)

Don't worry about `SU3C1` or `SU4C1`, those are capacitors. The pull-up resistor they were referring to in that post is probably `HR104`, but like I said I don't think that's our issue since we would have measured low at both `SU3` and `SU4`.

Try the following:

* Open a Terminal/Command Prompt/Powershell window (no admin privileges required) and run: `winget`

* Run: `winget install onedrive firefox`

If the tool asks you to allow the use of a certain source, accept that.

threads.content: It isn't a good sign that one software can recognise the IC and the other can't. The flash being full of Zeroes is another bad sign. If not being "bad" flash IC already, it points at least to interference or connection issues

threads.author: sephir0th1984
threads.content: Using the clip is bad practice to start with

threads.author: sephir0th1984
threads.content: Which would explain why you have issues

threads.author: sephir0th1984
threads.content: When using the clip it's very important to check the dump with a hex editor. Otherwise the original firmware might be lost already

threads.author: sephir0th1984
threads.content: Also it's a common issue that the flash IC can't be read or written in-circuit on many boards.

threads.author: sephir0th1984
threads.content: In these cases desoldering + programming board is the way to go

threads.author: sephir0th1984
threads.content: You will possibly write code which will be distorted when the flash IC receives it

threads.author: sephir0th1984
threads.content: Reverse logic applies here. You can use the clip when you know how to deal with corruption and how to minimise the risk. But not earlier...^^

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content:
Okay, so here is our procedure moving forward:
1. Back up current firmware and flash new firmware 
1.1. If nothing changes, restore old firmware
2. Attempt disabling the onboard RAM and falling back to DIMM
2.1. Check if there is a board ID strap we can use for this or if BIOS mods are needed
3. Lift the RAM
4. Lift the CPU

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: Of course, CPUs themselves and any kind of microcontroller literally provide JTAG debugging capability, but some hardware hacking may be needed and the tooling and experience needed would not be worth it. Plus, you'd need to reverse engineer the firmware still to find out where things are going wrong. The shops that go this far would just lift and replace the CPU. Faster, cheaper.

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: Sure, and Apple does the same thing.

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: But there's no catch-all for every motherboard. There are standards like ACPI Platform Error Interfaces (APEI) and Crash Log which I mentioned above, but you could spend a lifetime working on devices and maybe have that help you lead you to a problematic component a handful of times.

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: Of course, some desktop boards provide POST codes through a speaker, seven-segment display, or EZ Debug LEDs, but the only times those have helped me are for basic problems like when someone didn't install a CPU or RAM properly to begin with. Laptops often have blink codes, but you can ask Mike what he thinks about those.

threads.author: chrisis5300
threads.content:
Hi everyone,

I've an issue with a laptop. It's a compaq presario cq62. The laptop turn on for one second then shutdown immediatly. 

I've checked the psu coils, all are fine. The thing which is funny is that clicking sound corresponds to the main power rail voltage constantly changing from 19v to 0v. 

Do you have an idea and what can be the issue ?

Thanks for your help

threads.author: phoenix.yk
threads.content: Could be a *partially* shorted MOSFET or power ic *(anything really)* on that rail. Forward to #üíªlaptops

threads.author: chrisis5300
threads.content:
It was exactly that, thanks for your help, it helped me a lot !


Here's how I proceed : 
I took off the first MOSFET and then soldered one "proper calibrated wire" between the source and the drain. When I plugged the power, the laptop stopped clicking and the main power rail voltage stopped dropping and instead was constant 19v. 
I then replaced the MOSFET and rechecked and everything was ok !

threads.author: chrisis5300
threads.content:
I choosed arbitrarily one of the two MOSFET as I didn't have any clues on how to spot the faulty one. I got lucky.

Do you know how to check for a partially shorted MOSFET ?

threads.author: phoenix.yk
threads.content:
> *Do you know how to check for a partially shorted MOSFET ?*
Some clue is when it heats up disproportionately, or you get a lower resistance *(diode test)* reading on the partially shorted one compared with the exact other.

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: Just don't try to probe anything small. Hook your black probe into a screw standoff or something else that is grounded and don't touch it. Then just check voltage on each inductor. Each side of each coil should have plenty of surface area to measure without blowing things up.

threads.author: dhalon
threads.content: Is it safer on coils?

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: Yes, where else would you measure?

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: A coil is placed at the output of every major switching power supply on the board. They are the easiest to see and probe.

threads.author: dhalon
threads.content: Some resistors?

threads.author: dhalon
threads.content: Does it matter in which side of the coil is being checked?

threads.author: codeconnoisseur
threads.content: Just do both sides and record which has the more stable and reasonable voltage, which should always be the load side. Though, with most multimeters, either side should work.
